instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burned <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> USB-C controller
threads.message:
5V 0A on first USB-C connector
5V 0,29A on second

Removed <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, cleaned the mess, made sure leaded pads not shorted. 

we have short on cpu lines:
L3200 <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XB_N</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XB_P</SIGNAL> - shorted to ground
L3000 <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XA_N</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XA_P</SIGNAL> - shorted to ground

Is it worth putting new <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> or it's dead cpu and it's RIP time?

I appreciate your knowledge and time, many thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burned <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> USB-C controller
threads.message:
Apple schematic is a nightmare in tjis case.
Is not clear at all where the lines go.
=<SIGNAL>USB_UPC_XB_P</SIGNAL> is same as <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XB_P</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>NC_USB2_08P</SIGNAL>.
Last one goes to CPU in schematic, but also has "NC" marjing (Not Connected).
There also appears <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_XB_P</SIGNAL>, connected to ground through <RESISTOR>R3014</RESISTOR>; but not directly related with =<SIGNAL>USB_UPC_XB_P</SIGNAL> in schematic.

You should compare with working board, to discard any doubt.
Just in case, remove <RESISTOR>R3014</RESISTOR> and check if =<SIGNAL>USB_UPC_XB_P</SIGNAL> is still shorted to ground.
If yes, then bad CPU.
First look at USB redriver chip, if exists in your board; search the forum about it.
It could be connected there too and many times dies together with one of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burned <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> USB-C controller
threads.message:
After removing <RESISTOR>R3014</RESISTOR> =<SIGNAL>USB_UPC_XB_P</SIGNAL> is not shorted to ground.
but it still has short on these lines:
at L3200 <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XB_N</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XB_P</SIGNAL>
at L3000 <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XA_N</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XA_P</SIGNAL>

PI3USB32 seems clean not damaged. But did not find in forum how to inspect that chip.

What should I look for on good working board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burned <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> USB-C controller
threads.message:
Inspect for any small hole on top of redriver chip; or other sign of burnt.

If you still have short after removing <RESISTOR>R3015</RESISTOR>, then bad CPU.
Or redriver, if is connected there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burned <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> USB-C controller
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R3014</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3015</RESISTOR> lines are not shorted after remove.
Redriver has no visible signs (inspected under 45x microscope) of burn or damage.
Is there a way to test redriver or should I remove it and then check the shorted lines or just replace?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burned <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> USB-C controller
threads.message:
Do you still have short on any of above mentioned lines?
If yes, then bad CPU; or redriver, if connected there.
If short value is very low you, can probably heat the culprit injecting voltage.
